entry.et: Middle English, from Old English butere, from Latin butyrum, from Greek boutyron, from bous cow + tyros cheese; akin to Avestan tūiri- curds cow

def.dt: :a solid emulsion of fat globules, air, and water made by churning milk or cream and used as food
:a buttery substance: as
:any of various fatty oils remaining nearly solid at ordinary temperatures
:a creamy food spread
:one made of ground roasted nuts peanut butter
:flattery
:to spread with or as if with butter

entry.fl: noun plural but singular or plural in construction

def.dt: :a common Eurasian perennial herb (Linaria vulgaris) of the snapdragon family that has showy yellow and orange flowers and is naturalized in much of North America called also toadflax
:lima bean: as
:a dried lima bean
:sieva bean
:wax bean
:a green shell bean especially as opposed to a snap bean
:either of two edible clams (Saxidomus nuttallii and S. giganteus) of the Pacific coast of North America
:a lettuce (as Bibb or Boston lettuce) with a soft loose head of tender oily mild-flavored leaves
:to charm or beguile with lavish flattery or praise
:a thick brown spread made by cooking apples with sugar and spices usually in cider
:a means of sustenance or livelihood
:being as basic as the earning of one's livelihood bread–and–butter issues
:reliable our bread–and–butter repertoire
:dependable as a source of income a company's bread–and–butter products
:sent or given as thanks for hospitality a bread–and–butter letter
